node.title: Juana Molina – Paraguaya Punk
node.content:
Regardless of being a veteran, Argentinian musician Juana Molina has never ceased to amaze with original yet very approachable ideas in music.

Molina is one of the few heroes that show that you don’t have to turn into a legacy act just because you get older. The lucid understanding and the use of new technology have been and still are a defining mark on her original approach to musical composition and performance.

In this hand-drawn animation video of a punk version of her song Paraguaya taken from the 2017 album Halo we once again witness Molina’s clever musical ideas and youthful energy.

node.title: Nine Inch Nails – Ghosts V: Together (2020)
node.content:
Even today after more than three decades since the beginning his career, Trent Reznor keeps affirming that his musical vision is still relevant and closely in touch with the world and the current state of affairs that disturb our self-centered existence on this fragile planet.

Out of the two releases so far this year, this week we listen to the lighter, more ethereal and meditative one, Ghosts V: Together.

Ambient sounds and textures that are reminiscent of Brain Eno’s best work, complemented with masterfully crafted droning melodies drowned in long reverb.

node.title: King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard – Honey
node.content:
This week’s Video of the week slot goes to the hyper-productive King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizard and their depiction of Melbourne at nightfall.

We have to be honest here, we were a bit alienated by their previous releases Fishing for Fishies and Infest the Rats’ Nest. Yet, with this new video they seem to get back on the “right” path.

In the meanwhile, King Gizzard released another video Some of Us in which they reminds us of the problems the world had before the Covid-19 crisis. Despite the pandemics, humanity is still destined for extinction.

node.title: The Babe Rainbow – Today
node.content: It’s always summer with The Babe Rainbow! Their third studio album named “Today” brings positive vibes all over. A groovy bassline, a bit late 60s psychodelia, some bossa nova tunes and a pinch of Afrobeats. One cannot simply resist to chill with their music.
node.excerpt: Today by The Babe Rainbow It’s always summer with The Babe Rainbow! Their third studio album named “Today” brings positive vibes all over. A groovy bassline, a bit late 60s psychodelia, some bossa nova tunes and a pinch of Afrobeats. One cannot simply resist to chill with their music.

node.title: Vessels – The Sky Was Pink
node.content: Vessels – The Sky Was Pink (2012) A cover of James Holden’s remix of Nathan Fake’s classic.
node.excerpt: Vessels – The Sky Was Pink (2012) A cover of James Holden’s remix of Nathan Fake’s classic.

node.title: Earth – The Bees Made Honey In The Lion’s Skull
node.content: Lengthy, repetitive and mesmerizing melodies that slowly drown you into the distorted and eerie atmosphere.
node.excerpt: The Bees Made Honey In The Lion's Skull by Earth Lengthy, repetitive and mesmerizing melodies that slowly drown you into the distorted and eerie atmosphere.

node.title: Loscil – Equivalents
node.content: A yesteryear release by the the well-known ambient veteran. In perfect contract to the summer atmosphere and small mindlessness brought by it. Cold and desolate clouds reign over the soul to keep us cool and focused.
node.excerpt: Equivalents by loscil A yesteryear release by the the well-known ambient veteran. In perfect contract to the summer atmosphere and small mindlessness brought by it. Cold and desolate clouds reign over the soul to keep us cool and focused.

node.title: Roy Montgomery – Scenes From The South Island
node.content: Expanded reissue of New Zealand guitar pioneer Roy Montgomery’s rare and revered full-length, Scenes From The South Island, originally released in 1995 by west coast experimental / space rock label Drunken Fish. Recorded on both coasts on a pair of Tascam 4-tracks, the album is alternately wistful, windswept, skeletal, shredded, and strange. Solo guitar figures flow and fray through echo and empty space, evoking loss, long roads, and low-lit landscapes.

node.title: Holy Wave – Interloper
node.content: Originally formed in El Paso, Texas, Holy Wave carefully combines fluid forms of sacred surf sounds, droning riffs, and group vocals that haunt and harmonize in equal measure.
node.excerpt: Originally formed in El Paso, Texas, Holy Wave carefully combines fluid forms of sacred surf sounds, droning riffs, and group vocals that haunt and harmonize in equal measure.

node.title: A brief guide through Vienna’s record stores
node.content:
As a city known for its baroque and neoclassical architecture, it is pretty clear that Vienna has a classical appeal. Having its rich classical music background in mind, it could reasonably be expected that its main cultural offer would be geared towards the more or less aristocratic tastes. In this sense, we would think that the city has little to give us in terms of alternative culture and independent music. Yet, even though it might lack the contemporary hipness of other European capitals, this would surely be an understatement.

Before visiting the city, the only record store that I was aware of was Teuchtler Schallplattenhandlung u. Antiquariat, an old Viennese institution featured in the film Before sunrise. What I was not aware of, was that the city indeed has a decent number of jams that I would gladly revisit when hopefully coming to town once again. In this article, I present some of the most exciting Viennese record shops.

A quick tip: getting on the tram number 49 on Karl Renner station on the Ring will take you to Westbahnstrasse. Here you’ll find three record shops and you’ll be able to easily reach a number of others nearby.

Substance

Westbahnstrasse 16

If I had the time to visit only one record store in Vienna, Substance would be it. The store has a diverse catalog along with a well-maintained website. There you’ll find more recent releases of mostly independent labels. Definitely a favorite record store in Vienna.

Schallter

Westbahnstraße 13

When leaving Substance, turn to the right and cross Westbahstrasse. There you’ll find Schallter. It’s a record store that has a more eclectic offer when compared to Substance. Besides records, the store offers a wide array of HI-FI equipment. Although, if you are not living here, the chances are slim that you would buy a bulky amplifier.

Das Market

Zieglergasse 40

Das Market is yet another record shop almost on the same street. It is located on the intersection between Westbahnstraße and Zieglergasse. Unfortunately, the onset of the Covid-19 epidemic prevented us from visiting this place in its opening hours, although the store’s window looked quite interesting.

Galea records

Kaiserstraße 67

Further down the Westbahnstraße take a turn right on Kaiserstraße and you’ll find another record store in the same neighborhood. It is owned by an over-friendly and very chatty Slovenian who won’t leave you browse through the collection without telling a story or two. Once again, a more eclectic offer, including a large number of Yugoslav rock music as well as more recent music from the ex-Yu region.

Recordbag Music & Fashion

Kollergerngasse 4

Recordbag Music & Fashion is record shop near the pedestrian street Mariahilfer Str. It’s well stocked with mainly guitar music in a more classic sense. You could easily spend an hour or more here digging through the records on offer.

Rave up

Hofmühlgasse 1

Rave up is yet another small store in which you’ll find independent releases though older major releases are also on the shelves. It is a little bit further away, but still reachable on foot on a downhill path from Mariahilfer Str.

Totem Records

Zollergasse 18-20

Even if you are not able to find something in this mostly metal oriented record store (perhaps, some dark ambient?), it is worth the visit and experience its hidden-in-plain-sight occult interior.

Audiocenter

Judenpl. 9

If you happen to stroll through the center of Vienna, you might bump into Audiocenter on Judenplatz. Although a more conventional and mostly jazz oriented music store, it is quite viable to find records of other genres of music here. Among other releases, we bought Dead can Dance’s  Within the realm of a dying Sun. Definitely worth a visit.

Still, if all fails and you’re out of luck with the stores listed here, one final place that I would suggest is the Saturn located on Mariahilfer Str. Surprisingly, there is a wide array of records and the prices are quite decent. Of course, there are other stores as well, but these are our favorite ones.
